journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part F: Journal of Rail and Rapid Transit

title-group.article-title: Prediction uncertainties and inaccuracies resulting from common assumptions in modelling vibration from underground railways

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, Canada
2Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge, UK
3Department of Civil Engineering, University of Nottingham, UK

author-notes.corresp: Simon Jones, Department of Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, Montreal, Canada. Email: simon.jones2@mail.mcgill.ca

abstract.p: Underground railways produce significant ground-borne vibration that is reported to disturb people living or working near subways. Designers and engineers use numerical models to predict vibration levels so as to meet the increasingly strict vibration standards. These models commonly include simplifying assumptions to reduce the complexity and cost of the simulation. This paper reviews six commonly disregarded aspects of the underground railway environment and their respective effects on vibration prediction values: a second (twin) tunnel, piled foundations, track with discontinuous slabs, soil inhomogeneity, inclined soil layers, and irregular contact at the tunnel–soil interface. Results suggest that accounting for each of these simplifying assumptions can result in predictions that vary from the simplified cases by at least 5 dB and potentially up to 20 dB. This is a significant level of uncertainty and should be considered when estimating the predictive accuracy of numerical models using simplifying assumptions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Concern over increasing urban congestion and carbon emissions are two driving forces for the development of underground rail networks in cities. A significant issue arising from the development of these rail networks is the propagation of ground-borne noise and vibration into nearby buildings. The low-frequency noise and vibration produced by underground railways is a major disturbance to occupants, and is disruptive in the day-to-day operation of vibration-sensitive premises.1–3 In order for designers to meet the increasingly strict vibration standards, accurate models of the underground environment that can predict surface noise and vibration levels are greatly sought after. However, the number of parameters involved in describing the underground environment makes formulation of a comprehensive model of vibration from underground railways a virtually impossible task.

All currently available prediction models are based upon simplifying assumptions in some form, ranging from the global scale (modelling a single tunnel when it is known there are additional tunnels in the near vicinity) to local scale (assuming the soil is homogeneous when experiments show local variation of soil properties). These simplifying assumptions may be imposed based upon available computational power, engineering intuition or because complete empirical data of the simulation site is not known.

Simplifying assumptions introduce inaccuracy and uncertainty into the predictions, and in many cases, these inaccuracies and uncertainties remain unquantified. This paper reviews six commonly disregarded aspects of the underground railway environment: a second (twin) tunnel, piled foundations, track with discontinuous slabs, soil inhomogeneity, inclined soil layers and irregular contact at the tunnel–soil interface. For each of these features, modelling predictions that quantify the influence of the assumption on the vibration levels are presented. For the sake of brevity, full details of these models are not presented here, but the interested reader is referred, in each section, to relevant literature.

sec.title: Twin tunnels
sec.p: The majority of underground railway lines around the world consist of two tunnels of identical construction: one for the outbound direction and one for the inbound direction. These tunnels are usually located side-by-side, but occasionally, such as in the case of the Chungho Line in Taipei, the tunnels are located at intermediate orientations.4 Twin-tunnel construction is preferred because incorporating both the inbound and outbound railway lines into one large tunnel results in a larger volume of excavated material and more involved construction techniques.5

Models for the dynamic behaviour of twin tunnels are found in the field of earthquake engineering. The seismic modelling of twin-tunnel dynamics has its origins in the mutual interaction of multiple obstacles with wavefields, a topic that has been discussed in the literature for over a century and is of interest to many disciplines, including acoustics, electromagnetics and quantum mechanics. This problem is resolved using numerical or analytical methods. The numerical methods include the finite-difference method, the finite-element method and the boundary-element method, all of which can be used to analyse arbitrary-shaped tunnels. The analytical method is the wave-function expansion method, which expresses the total displacement wavefield as the superposition of the incident, reflected and diffracted wavefields. Many more models exist for the mutual interaction of twin voids or inclusions with wavefields.

It is common practice to ignore the effect of a twin tunnel when modelling underground railway vibration. The only dynamic model that accounts for the vibration interaction between neighbouring tunnels is the coupled wavenumber finite element--boundary element (FE--BE) model.6 This model compares the response of a large, single-bore double-track tunnel and a pair of single twin-track tunnels embedded in an elastic half-space.

A novel solution for two parallel tunnels of circular cross-section in a homogeneous, elastic soil full space has been developed.7 This model is an extension of the Pipe-in-Pipe (PiP) model for a single tunnel.8 PiP is a three-dimensional model for an underground tunnel embedded in a full space and is developed by using the elastic wave equations for two concentric pipes with infinite length.9–11 The internal pipe simulates the tunnel wall and the external pipe, with internal radius equal to the external radius of the tunnel and external radius of infinite extent, models a full space with cylindrical cavity. These two pipes are coupled by considering equilibrium of forces and compatibility of displacements at the tunnel–soil interface. The model accounts for interaction between the train, track, tunnel and soil; specific rail infrastructure such as discontinuous slab track can be included (see the section on discontinuous slab tracks), where the excitation is in the form of a pull-through unit roughness spectrum at the wheel–rail interface. PiP has further been developed to model a tunnel embedded in a half-space12 and a tunnel embedded in a multi-layered half-space.13 The efficiency of computations of PiP to model tunnels embedded in a half-space or layered half-space are significantly higher than other discretization models such as the coupled FE-BE model. It is reported that PiP takes a minute to calculate vibration at a point in the soil due to a source in a tunnel embedded in a layered half-space, while the coupled FE-BE method takes 17 hrs to perform the same calculations with the same accuracy.13

In the two-tunnel model, the tunnels are modelled as thin-walled cylinders and known dynamic train forces are applied at each of the tunnel inverts. The net applied load per unit area acting on each of the two tunnels is equal to the difference between the tractions resulting from the known dynamic train forces (P~1, P~2) and the tractions resulting from the dynamic cavity forces (Q~1, Q~2). This is illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1.
A free-body diagram showing the tractions resulting from the dynamic train forces and the dynamic cavity forces.

The vibration response of the two-cavity system can be written as the superposition of two displacement fields. One displacement field is the result of forces acting on a single cavity (similar to a direct field), while the other displacement field is the result of the interactions between the two cavities (similar to a scattered field). The tractions resulting from the dynamic cavity forces are written as the sum of two contributions: those traction vectors acting on a single cavity (F~1 and F~2), and those traction vectors representing the motion induced by the neighbouring cavity (G~1 and G~2). This is illustrated in Figure 2. Figure 2.
The tractions resulting from the dynamic cavity forces are written as the sum of two contributions: those traction vectors acting on a single cavity and those representing the motion induced by the neighbouring cavity.

The interaction terms G~1 and G~2 are expressed in terms of the variables F~1 and F~2 by writing the traction vectors representing the motion induced by the neighbouring cavity as a function of the traction vectors acting directly on the neighbouring cavity. To calculate the traction vectors representing the motion induced by the neighbouring cavity, the equations for a single-cavity model are used to determine the stresses around the virtual surface of the neighbouring cavity. The soil-continuum equations are then used to transform these stresses into the equivalent traction vector acting on the neighbouring cavity. The advantage of this method is that by apportioning the known traction vectors in this way, it is only ever necessary to consider a single-cavity system at any time.

Using the equations for a thin-walled cylinder, the net applied load per unit area acting on each of the two tunnels can be expressed as a function of the tunnel displacements. The displacements of the two-tunnel system are equal to the displacements of the two-cavity system, and equal to the displacements of the two tunnels, by compatibility of displacements. The principle of superposition can again be used to write the displacements of the two-cavity system as the sum of those displacements resulting from the traction vectors F~1 and F~2 acting on a single cavity, and those displacements resulting from the interactions between the two cavities. This is illustrated in Figure 3. Figure 3.
The displacements of the two-cavity system are written as the sum of two contributions: those displacements resulting from the loads acting on a single cavity, and those resulting from the interactions between the two cavities.

These traction vectors include components for every coordinate direction, modenumber, wavenumber and frequency. The end result of this formulation is a series of simultaneous equations, the solution of which represents the traction vectors F~1 and F~2 applied to the single-cavity models to replicate the displacement field produced by the known traction vectors P~1 and P~2 applied to the two-tunnel model. The displacement field of the two-tunnel model is thus the superposition of the displacement field produced by the traction vector F~1 acting on cavity 1 in a single-cavity model, and the displacement field produced by the traction vector F~2 acting on cavity 2 in a single-cavity model.

The inaccuracy that exists in vibration prediction models that include only one of the two tunnels present can be quantified using insertion gains (IGs). The IGs essentially represent the change in the vibration response at any given location when a two-tunnel model is employed, and are calculated as the ratio of the vibration response of a two-tunnel model to that of a single-tunnel model. Figures 4–6 illustrate the steps taken when calculating the IG. A region of large magnitude IG indicates that the assumption of a single-tunnel system will result in predictions for this region with a high degree of inaccuracy. For example, in Figure 6, the region above the right-hand tunnel predicts twin-tunnel vibration levels of the order of 20 dB greater than those predicted by the single-tunnel model, using the model parameters listed in Table 1. Figure 4.
The vertical displacement field in dB (ref 1 m) produced at 100 Hz by a unit, vertical point force applied to a tunnel invert, calculated using a single-tunnel model. Figure 5.
The vertical displacement field in dB (ref 1 m) produced at 100 Hz by a unit, vertical point force applied to a tunnel invert, calculated using a twin-tunnel model. Figure 6.
The IG (dB) represents the difference between the vertical displacement fields produced at 100 Hz by the single-tunnel model and the twin-tunnel model. Table 1.
Parameter values used for tunnel and soil models.
Value
Tunnel properties
Density 2500 kg/m3
Shear modulus 19.2 GPa
Poisson's ratio 0.30
Radius 3 m
Thickness 0.25 m
Soil properties
Density 2000 kg/m3
Young's modulus 550 MPa
Poisson's ratio 0.44

Further investigations of the vibration fields produced over a range of frequencies, tunnel orientations and tunnel geometries indicates that the interactions between neighbouring tunnels are highly significant, at times of the order of 20 dB. The vibration response is observed to be highly dependent on frequency, position, material properties and underground environment. Any surface vibration prediction model that includes only one of the two tunnels should be recognized to contain a high degree of inaccuracy, and it is strongly recommended that future models predicting vibration levels from underground railways include the interactions between neighbouring tunnels. These results also imply that when vibration-attenuating solutions, such as floating slab tracks, are installed in tunnels based on the predictions of a single-tunnel model, the amount of attenuation achieved at the surface may not be as large as the single-tunnel model predicts, due to the interaction of the second tunnel.

sec.title: Piled foundations
sec.p: The presence of embedded structures, such as piled foundations, are often ignored in predictive models, yet the proximity of these structures to underground railways suggests that they play a significant role in the transmission of ground-borne vibration, and subsequently the production of ground-borne noise.

Many well-established models exist for the dynamic behaviour of piled foundations, either due to an incident seismic wavefield or an inertial loading, for example Novak,14 Sen et al.15 and Kuhlemeyer.16 Examples of models that consider the interaction of railways and piled foundations include Ju,17 Wu and Yang18 and Lu et al.19 All these models consider above-ground railways and piled foundations that are either supporting the railway or are installed as vibration-reducing measures. There is no evidence in the literature for a comprehensive model of piled foundations subject to a wavefield generated by an underground railway. It is thought that the lack of such a model is due to the complexity of modelling such a system, particularly the large number of elements required and subsequent increase in computation time when using numerical finite-element or boundary-element models.

An efficient semi-analytical model of pile groups subject to vibration from an underground railway has been formulated as a useful design tool, which can be used to make qualitative assessments of the impact of piles on vibration levels.20 This model is an uncoupled source–receiver model, as the method of coupling of subsystems21 is used to join one subsystem, the underground railway model, to the other subsystem, the pile-group model. The use of an uncoupled source–receiver model is justified by a study by Coulier et al.,22 who show that accounting for the coupling between the source and receiver results in deviations of the order of ±2 dB. This level of deviation is small compared to the uncertainty levels present in ground-borne vibration predictions.

The incident wavefield produced by the underground railway is generated using the PiP model, and the displacements produced at the pile locations by this incident wavefield are used as the input excitations for the pile-group model.

Each individual pile is modelled as a column in axial vibration or a Euler–Bernoulli beam in lateral vibration. The soil is modelled as an elastic continuum with outer radius of infinity and inner radius equal to the pile radius. Combining the elastic continuum equations with the boundary conditions restricting motion to one direction at the soil–pile interface results in the soil being represented by a stiffness function in the wavenumber domain. The soil stiffness is included in the standard equation for vibration of an infinite column or beam subject to a unit harmonic excitation to obtain the response of the pile in the wavenumber domain in the axial and lateral directions, respectively. The mirror-image method is used to obtain an approximate response for a finite pile from these infinite pile equations. The mirror-image method involves applying scaled forces and moments at two points equidistant from the required end condition. By scaling the forces and moments to be equal and opposite to those forces and moments already existing in the infinite pile, a free end can be created. Excellent agreement is observed between the response of a single pile generated using this method, and the results of a boundary-element model.20

When modelling pile groups, it is necessary to account for the interactions occurring between neighbouring piles, also known as pile–soil–pile interactions (PSPIs). These interactions are commonly quantified using the interaction factor (α): a measure of how the excitation of one pile affects the pile-head displacement of a neighbouring pile. The interaction factors for the elastic continuum model are calculated using an uncoupled source–receiver model. The response of a pile group to excitation from an underground railway can then be determined by calculating the response of each individual pile to the incident wavefield, and accounting for PSPIs by multiplying the response of each pile by the relevant interaction factors. The sum of the single pile and PSPI contributions then represents the pile-group response. Figure 7 presents an example of the axial interaction factors for concrete piles calculated using this method, in comparison to a boundary-element model developed by Coulier,23 and very good agreement is observed. Figure 7.
The real part (top) and imaginary part (bottom) of the axial interaction factors at a pile separation distance of 10 times the pile radii. BE: boundary-element.

To illustrate how the presence of piled foundations can affect surface vibration predictions, Figure 8 compares the vertical vibration levels as a function of frequency at the pile head for a four-pile foundation, and at the corresponding location when there is no foundation present. The soil, tunnel and pile parameters are given in Tables 1 and 2; the origin of the tunnel is 25 m below the surface. The material properties have been chosen here to represent concrete piles embedded in London Clay. It can be seen that in this case, the inaccuracy inherent in a prediction which ignores the presence of piled foundations is highly dependent on frequency, and can range from −15 dB to +8 dB. This represents a significant margin for a prediction model of vibration from underground railways. Figure 8.
The vertical response of the (a) outer and (b) inner piles in a four-pile group subject to an incident wavefield generated using the PiP software. Table 2.
Parameter values used for the pile-group model.
Pile properties Value
Density 2500 kg/m3
Young's modulus 30 GPa
Poisson's ratio 0.25
Length 5 m
Radius 0.35 m
Pile separation 1.5 m

sec.title: Discontinuous slab tracks
sec.p:
One of the effective means to reduce vibration from underground railways is the use of floating slab tracks.24–26 As shown in Figure 9, these tracks are constructed by supporting the rails on a slab with a large mass. The slab is supported via soft resilient elements on the track bed. The slab can be cast in situ, resulting in a track with a continuous slab, and it can be constructed in discrete pre-cast sections, leading to a track with a discontinuous slab. Examples of floating slab tracks are the 1.5 m slab in Toronto, the 3.4 m Eisenmann track in Munich and Frankfurt, the 7 m slab in New York subway and the continuous slab system in the Washington DC Metro. Figure 9.
Floating slab track.

A track with continuous slab can be modelled using the PiP method for a tunnel embedded in a full space9 or a half-space.12 A track with a discontinuous slab can be modelled using the periodic-infinite structure theory to couple a periodic track to a continuous model of a tunnel embedded in the ground.27

Vibration due to a single 1000 kg wheel-set of a train moving with a constant velocity of 12 m/s on a track with continuous and discontinuous slabs is presented in Hussein.28 A white noise roughness is considered for the two tracks; rails of type UIC60 are simulated using the parameters shown in Table 3 for a 20 m deep tunnel with properties given in Table 1. For a given wavelength of the rail roughness, a moving wheel-set on a continuous track results in a dynamic force at a single frequency, unlike for a wheel-set on a discontinuous track, which results in a sum of forces with different frequencies. Table 3.
Floating slab track properties.
Property Rail Slab
Mass 120.6 kg/m 3500 kg/m
Bending stiffness 12.9 MPa.m4 1430 MPa.m4
Loss factor 0.02 0.05
Railpad Slab bearing
Stiffness 200 MN/m/m 5 MN/m/m
Loss factor 0.15 0.15

Figure 10 shows a sample result of the power spectral density of the vertical displacement at a point in the free surface of a homogeneous ground due to a single wheel-set moving on two types of tracks: a floating slab track with a continuous slab and a floating slab track with a discontinuous slab. Figure 10.
Power spectral density for a continuous (solid line) and a discontinuous (dashed line) floating slab track.

It can be seen from Figure 10 that for both tracks, a pronounced peak occurs at a frequency of 80 Hz, corresponding to the wheel–track resonance frequency. For the track with a discontinuous slab, more peaks show (i.e. at approximately 65 Hz and 175 Hz), and these correspond to resonances of the discrete slab and can be calculated using the equation of the natural frequencies of a free–free beam.28 A final remark about this figure is that vibration from a floating slab track with a discontinuous slab is different to that for a track with a continuous slab by up to about 10 dB. The maximum difference occurs at about 150 Hz, and is attributed to attenuation of response produced by the discrete slab following its first resonance frequency. This example demonstrates a shortcoming of using a continuous track model to account for a track with a discontinuous slab.

sec.title: Soil inhomogeneity
sec.p: Predictive models often assume the soil region of an underground railway simulation is a homogeneous half-space to simplify the modelling process. However, the dynamic properties of soils are difficult to measure, and can vary significantly over the area of interest. Experimental testing shows that dynamic soil properties can easily vary ±10% for test sites just metres apart; Phoon and Kulhawy29 show coefficients of variation (COV = standard deviation divided by the mean) for soil wavespeeds that range from 15% to 65%. This suggests that assuming homogeneous soil properties may not be sufficient for accurate representation of wave propagation from underground railways.

To investigate the effect of soil inhomogeneity on ground vibration, a semi-analytical model has been developed that employs a thin-layer method (TLM), including hyperelements to mesh the region of interest.30 Hyperelements can be finite or infinite in length as they utilize the analytical solution for a wave propagating horizontally while assuming vertical displacements vary linearly through the thickness of the element. This formulation negates aspect ratio restrictions common to finite element (FE) modelling, thus, a half-space can be accurately modelled using relatively few elements. Vertical discretization must be sufficient to capture the highest frequency of interest; 16 elements per shear wavelength is found to be appropriate.30

Using the TLM model the elastic modulus of the soil is varied using a non-Gaussian K–L expansion of a two-dimensional (2D) modified exponential covariance kernel which results in a COV of 30% through the soil model (see Figure 11 for an example). A total of 500 realizations of the soil variation are used to predict a 90% confidence interval for vertical root mean square (rms) surface velocity of a half-space subjected to underground railway loading. Tunnel loading is included using the equivalent internal source method, which is an extension of the PiP method.12 Figure 11.
Example realization of local variation in soil elastic modulus.

The curves in Figure 12 display the results at four third-octave frequency bands: 25 Hz, 50 Hz, 100 Hz and 160 Hz using the model properties listed in Table 1 and a tunnel depth of 15 m. The results show that the 90% confidence interval is relatively small at lower frequencies (±3 dB, ref 1 m/s), but grows substantially with frequency to reach ±12 dB in the 160 Hz frequency band. Figure 12.
Vertical rms velocity along surface of a half-space with inhomogeneous soil properties (solid line: homogeneous TLM prediction; grey area: 90% confidence interval). (a) 25 Hz, (b) 50 Hz, (c) 100 Hz and (d) 160 Hz frequency band.

Research into the effect of soil inhomogeneity is continuing, but these preliminary results suggest it is necessary to include at least a ±5 dB uncertainty range when simulating ground vibration using simplified soil models.

sec.title: Inclined soil layers
sec.p:
Much like the simplifications to local soil variability described in the previous section, global soil stratification is also commonly simplified during model development. The simplest soil geometry is a homogeneous half-space; if sufficient evidence is available to warrant the extra complexity, horizontal layers of homogeneous soils may be also incorporated. Using horizontal layering results in a geometrically simple model, which reduces the modelling complexity and the computational requirements for a solution. While these are useful assumptions during model development, real soil stratification tends to vary in inclination angle. Figure 13 shows a rendition of a soil lithology taken from a geological survey. Notice the slight inclination of the layers with respect to the surface; it is not uncommon to have layer inclinations of 5°. It is unclear how the inclination of a soil layer affects the global vibration response of the soil and hence the prediction accuracy of the simplified models. Figure 13.
Rendition of an actual soil lithology.

To investigate the effect of inclined soil layers, the 2D TLM is again used for its efficiency and accuracy in simulating vibration from underground railways, as detailed by Jones and Hunt.31 The 2D approach has been shown to be acceptable when determining relative differences between different soil assumptions.32 A schematic of the inclined layer half-space model used in the study is given in Figure 14. As the hyperelement geometry is rectangular, it is not possible to simulate the exact interface between the layer and the half-space. Instead, the inclined interface is approximated in step-wise fashion as shown; inclination angles of θ = [1°; 3°; 5°] are simulated. The properties of the base half-space material are given in Table 1, while the properties of the upper layer are varied to produce layer wavespeeds that are either twice or half that of the half-space. Tunnel loading is again included using the equivalent internal source method. Figure 14.
TLM step-wise representation of an inclined layer. (a) Schematic of inclined layer coupled to half space and (b) TLM mesh for inclined layer model.

A comparison of the predicted surface vibrations at varying layer inclination angles is presented as the dB difference between the inclined and horizontal layer results. For lack of a better term, this difference will be referred to as IG. A positive IG signifies an increase in surface vibration due to layer inclination compared to a horizontal layer of equivalent material, whereas a negative IG signifies a decrease in vibration. The predicted surface rms velocity IGs calculated for a frequency range of 15–200 Hz are presented in Figure 15 for velocities in the vertical directions. In Figure 15(a), the layer has been defined with a shear wavespeed twice that of the underlying half-space, and in Figure 15(b), the layer has a shear wavespeed half that of the half-space. Figure 15.
rms velocity along a surface with a 5 m layer inclined at various angles (solid line: 1°; dashed line: 3°; dash-dotted line: 5°). (a) clayer = 2 chalf–space and (b) clayer = 0.5 chalf–space.

The figures show an apparent deflection of wave energy due to refraction at the inclined layer interface. There is a distinct upward slope to the rms velocity IG for case (a) resulting from the refraction of wave energy to the right, whereas there is a downward slope to the IG for case (b). This response agrees with the theoretical response predicted by the law of refraction for a wavefront passing through an inclined layer separating materials of different wavespeeds.31 For the 1° case, this results in only approximately ±1 dB rms, but for a 5° inclination angle, the IG reaches 6 dB rms for case (a) and 7 dB rms for case (b). This level of IG for small inclination angles is significant and suggests that uncertainty in soil lithology should be considered when stating the prediction accuracy of a simplified model. Future research aims to investigate layer inclination in the longitudinal direction; this is currently not possible due to the 2D formulation used for this simulation.

sec.title: Voids at the tunnel–soil interface
sec.p: Another simplifying assumption frequently made is that the soil is in continuous contact with the tunnel (ie. no voids or gaps at the tunnel–soil interface). Subsidence and frost heave have been shown to cause significant tunnel movement;33,34 under such large-scale motion, it is likely that a void will form over a section of the tunnel, disrupting the perfect bond at the tunnel–soil interface. Voids may also develop during construction of new buildings in close proximity to the underground tunnels due to pile driving, excavation or landscaping. The extent of voidage is difficult, if not impossible, to quantify, but the existence of voids is not in doubt.

Development of a fully analytical model to investigate the effect of a void at the tunnel–soil interface on surface vibration was deemed intractable; thus, a semi-analytical approach was adopted.35 The tunnel–soil interface is discretized and the PiP method is used to determine the discrete transfer functions for both the tunnel and the surrounding soil nodes. The transfer matrices are coupled using continuity and equilibrium conditions. The void is simulated by uncoupling the appropriate tunnel and soil nodes, inhibiting the transfer of forces between the two subsystems over a finite patch. Empirically derived rail roughness is used to compute the random-process force input to the tunnel invert. A schematic of the void model geometry showing the tunnel, observation plane, load location and void placement is given in Figure 16; full details on the modelling process can be found in Jones and Hunt.35 Figure 16.
Void model geometry showing the location of the observation plane.

An example of the effect of a void on near-field and far-field rms particle velocity is shown in Figure 17 for a 4 m × 90° void centred on the top of the tunnel; tunnel and soil properties are given in Table 1. The results are shown in IG, where positive values signify an increase in rms velocity when the void is present compared to a continuous soil–tunnel bond. Figure 17.
IG response in dB (rms, ref 1 m/s) for a 4 m × 90° void; load at x = 0 in tunnel. (a) 25 Hz, (b) 50 Hz, (c) 100 Hz and (d) 60 Hz passband.

The figure shows that the IG increases at higher frequency bands. This is attributed to how the vibration energy is transformed into pressure and shear waves when a void is present at the tunnel–soil interface. Since there is no force transmission at the void site, motion of the tunnel at this location will not directly result in wave propagation. Figure 18 shows the vertical response of the tunnel for a void-free case at 25 Hz and 160 Hz. The average wavelength at 25 Hz is approximately 13 m, while at 160 Hz, it is approximately 5 m. The void length in the example is 4 m, which is relatively small compared to the 25 Hz wavelength, thus, the bulk of the wavelength bridges the void; the effect at the observation plane is therefore relatively small (±1 dB). At 160 Hz, the void length is more substantial relative to the wavelength, thus, it has a greater effect; the void accounts for almost a whole wavelength, thus, a significant amount of energy is not transmitted to the soil above the tunnel, resulting in moderate IGs (±5 dB). The lack of force transmission at the void results in higher interface forces elsewhere around the tunnel, thus, energy localization in the wavefronts occurs relative to the void-free case. This explains why the void causes IG losses at some locations (no force transmission across the void) and IG increases at others (energy localization to other areas of the tunnel–soil interface). Figure 18.
Vertical response of tunnel at (a) 25 Hz and (b) 160 Hz (length measured from load location at x = 0).

The findings from this study suggest that the uncertainty associated with assuming a perfect bond at the tunnel–soil interface in an area with known voidage can reasonably reach 5 dB and thus should be accounted for in the design process.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Accurate modelling of ground vibration due to underground railways is of great interest for designers who must adhere to the noise and vibration standards for developments near subway lines. Simplifying modelling assumptions are often used as the number of parameters involved in describing the underground environment makes formulation of a comprehensive model intractable; these simplifying assumptions introduce inaccuracy and uncertainty into the predictions. This paper quantifies the effect of six commonly disregarded aspects of the underground railway environment: a second (twin) tunnel, piled foundations, track with discontinuous slabs, soil inhomogeneity, inclined soil layers and voids at the tunnel–soil interface. Results suggest that accounting for each of these simplifying assumptions can result in predictions that vary from the simplified cases by at least 5 dB and potentially up to 20 dB. This is a significant level of uncertainty and should be considered when estimating the predictive accuracy of numerical models using simplifying assumptions.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported in part by the Gates Cambridge Trust, the Natural Science and Engineering Research Council of Canada, the General Sir John Monash Foundation and King's College Cambridge.
